questions.question: A 7-year-old child presents with a sore throat, fever, and tender cervical lymphadenopathy. A rapid antigen detection test for Group A Streptococcus is positive. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.A: Prescribe oral penicillin V for 10 days
options.B: Perform a throat culture to confirm the diagnosis
options.C: Administer a single dose of intramuscular benzathine penicillin G

questions.explanation: case is Group A Streptococcal pharyngitis . Oral penicillin V for 10 days is the first-line treatment for Group A Streptococcal pharyngitis in most cases. It helps prevent rheumatic fever. The 10-day course is recommended to ensure complete eradication of the organism. Gram Stain Gram-positive cocci in chains Appearance on Blood Agar Pinpoint colonies with a wide zone of hemolysis Indicates beta-hemolysis Transport Medium Pike's media Selective Media PNF (Phenylethyl alcohol agar), Crystal Violet Blood Agar (CVBA) Liquid Media Granular turbidity Suggests the presence of streptococci, as these organisms can cause cloudiness in liquid media. Biochemical Tests Result Catalase Test Negative Oxidase Test Negative PYR Test Positive Bacitracin Sensitivity Sensitive Antibiotic Dosage (Children) Dosage (Adolescents/Adults) Special Notes Penicillin V (Oral) 250 mg 2–3 times daily for 10 days 250 mg 4 times daily or 500 mg twice daily for 10 days First-line oral treatment; is effective and inexpensive. Amoxicillin (Oral) 50 mg/kg once daily (max 1000 mg) or 25 mg/kg twice daily (max 500 mg) for 10 days N/A Preferred for younger children due to better palatability; similar efficacy to penicillin. Benzathine Penicillin G (IM) 600,000 U (for children <27 kg) 1 dose 1,200,000 U (for children ≥ 27 kg) 1 dose N/A For patients who cannot tolerate oral therapy or have poor adherence to a 10-day regimen. Other options: Perform Throat Culture(Option B): for Group A Streptococcus has high specificity. A positive Rapid Antigen Detection Test result in a symptomatic patient is sufficient for diagnosis and treatment initiation without the need for throat culture confirmation. Intramuscular benzathine penicillin G (Option C): is not the first-line option for uncomplicated cases. Usually reserved for patients who cannot tolerate oral medication or where compliance is a concern. Azithromycin (Option D): is an alternative for patients with penicillin allergy. However, it is not the first-line treatment due to increasing resistance rates and should be reserved for specific situations. Reference: Bailey & Scott's Diagnostic Microbiology, 14th Edition, pp. 254-256 Murray's Medical Microbiology, 9th Edition, pp. 198-200 Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 11th Edition, pp. 199-201 https:/ /www.cdc.gov/group-a-strep/hcp/clinical-guidance/strep-throat.html#:~:text=Penicillin%20or%20amoxicillin%20is %20the,Antibiotic%20resistance

questions.question: A 40-year-old man presents with a persistent cough and purulent sputum. He has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and frequent respiratory infections. A sputum sample is sent for culture, which grows a gram-negative diplococcus that is oxidase positive and butyrate esterase positive. What is the most likely pathogen?
questions.explanation: that is oxidase positive and butyrate esterase positive. It is commonly associated with respiratory tract infections, especially in individuals with chronic lung conditions like COPD. Moraxella Catarrhalis and Lacunata: Characteristic Moraxella Catarrhalis Moraxella Lacunata (axenfeld) Gram Stain Gram-negative diplococci Gram-negative coccobacilli Growth on Blood Agar and Chocolate Agar Smooth, opaque, grayish-white colonies Smooth, spreading colonies with a pit in the center Catalase Test Positive Positive Oxidase Test Positive Positive DNase Test Positive Negative Butyrate Esterase Test Positive Negative Nitrate Reduction Test Positive Positive Sugar Fermentation Does not ferment sugars Does not ferment sugars Common Infections Otitis media, sinusitis, bronchitis, pneumonia Conjunctivitis (not a common pathogen) Virulence Factors Beta-lactamase production, immune evasion mechanisms Less characterized Typical Symptoms Ear pain, nasal congestion, cough, fever, respiratory distress Redness, itching, discharge from the eyes Transmission Respiratory droplets Direct contact with contaminated surfaces or secretions Antibiotic Susceptibility Generally susceptible to beta-lactamase inhibitors, macrolides, and fluoroquinolones Typically sensitive to similar antibiotics but less commonly treated due to lower pathogenicity M. Lacunata (Option A) is generally associated with ocular infections, such as conjunctivitis, and is not typically found in respiratory infections. Additionally, Moraxella lacunata is DNase negative and butyrate esterase negative N. Meningitidis (Option B) is a gram-negative diplococcus and oxidase positive, it is primarily associated with meningitis and septicemia, not respiratory infections. It does not produce butyrate esterase. H. Influenzae (Option D) is a gram-negative coccobacillus, not a diplococcus. While it can cause respiratory infections, it does not match the described gram stain and biochemical characteristics. Reference: Bailey & Scott's Diagnostic Microbiology, 14th Edition, Page 419, 420, 421, 422, 423, 495, 496, 497, 498, 499, 500, 501, 502, 503

questions.question: A 25-year-old male presents to the clinic with a 5-day history of dysuria and purulent urethral discharge. He reports having unprotected sexual intercourse with a new partner two weeks ago. Gram stain of the urethral discharge reveals gram-negative diplococci within polymorphonuclear leukocytes. What is the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient?
questions.explanation: due to its efficacy and low resistance rates. It is recommended to administer it intramuscularly at a dose of 500 mg for uncomplicated gonorrhea. Neisseria Gonorrhoeae: Clinical Features Men Urethritis, purulent urethral discharge, dysuria, epididymitis, prostatitis. Women Cervicitis, vaginal discharge, pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), dysuria, and intermenstrual bleeding. Rarely can cause Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome. Pharyngeal Infection Often asymptomatic, sore throat, pharyngitis. Rectal Infection Proctitis, rectal discharge, pain, and tenesmus, may be asymptomatic. Disseminated Gonococcal Infection (DGI) Fever, dermatitis, polyarthralgia, septic arthritis. Neonates Ophthalmia neonatorum, conjunctivitis, potential for blindness if untreated. Diagnosis Gram Stain Gram-negative diplococci within polymorphonuclear leukocytes (particularly useful in men). Culture Thayer-Martin or other selective media, oxidase-positive, and carbohydrate utilization tests. NAAT (Nucleic Acid Amplification Test) Highly sensitive and specific, recommended for urogenital, pharyngeal, and rectal specimens. Serological Tests Not commonly used due to lower sensitivity and specificity compared to NAAT and culture. Treatment- Green STD kit First-Line Therapy Ceftriaxone 500 mg IM as a single dose PLUS doxycycline 100 mg orally twice daily for 7 days (if chlamydial co-infection is not excluded). Alternative Therapy Gentamicin 240 mg IM as a single dose PLUS azithromycin 2 g orally as a single dose (if ceftriaxone is not available). Azithromycin (Option B) is an alternative treatment if ceftriaxone is unavailable or if the patient has a severe allergy to cephalosporins. Doxycycline (Option C) is used to treat co-infection with Chlamydia trachomatis but is not effective as monotherapy for Neisseria gonorrhoeae. It should be used in conjunction with ceftriaxone for comprehensive treatment. Ciprofloxacin (Option D): Fluoroquinolones, including ciprofloxacin, were previously used for gonococcal infections, but due to widespread resistance, they are no longer recommended as a first-line treatment. Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th Edition, Page 236, 237

questions.question: A 19-year-old college student presents to the emergency department with high fever, severe headache, neck stiffness, and a petechial rash. Lumbar puncture is performed, and the CSF analysis shows elevated white blood cell count with a predominance of neutrophils, elevated protein, and decreased glucose levels. Gram stain reveals gram-negative diplococci, confirming Neisseria meningitidis. What is the most appropriate initial empirical antibiotic therapy for this patient?
questions.explanation: effective against Neisseria meningitidis. It penetrates the blood-brain barrier well and provides broad-spectrum coverage against other possible bacterial pathogens in cases of bacterial meningitis. Cefotaxime is an alternative with similar efficacy. Empirical Antibiotic Therapy : Ceftriaxone or Cefotaxime : First-line treatment for suspected bacterial meningitis, including Neisseria meningitidis. Vancomycin : Added empirically to cover potential penicillin-resistant Streptococcus pneumoniae until the pathogen is identified. (Option B ruled out) Ampicillin : Added if Listeria monocytogenes is suspected, especially in immunocompromised patients and the elderly. (Option C ruled out) Definitive Therapy : Penicillin G : The antibiotic of choice for confirmed Neisseria meningitidis, given intravenously. Alternative Antibiotics : Ceftriaxone or cefotaxime can be continued if the pathogen is confirmed to be susceptible. Duration : Treatment typically lasts 7 days. Dexamethasone : May be used to reduce inflammation and neurological complications, particularly if started before or with the first dose of antibiotics. Chemoprophylaxis for Close Contacts: Rifampin : 600 mg every 12 hours for 2 days (adults); 10 mg/kg every 12 hours for 2 days (children). Ciprofloxacin : A single dose of 500 mg (adults); not typically used in children. (Option D ruled out) Ceftriaxone : A single intramuscular dose of 250 mg (adults) or 125 mg (children). Vaccination Prophylaxis: Meningococcal polysaccharide vaccines (serogroups A, C, Y, and W135) administered as 2 doses to children aged 3-18 months or a single dose to older children and adults. It is not given to children less than 2-3 years of age. Indications- Contacts of patients during outbreaks Splenic dysfunction Terminal complement component deficiency International travelers Reference: Apurba Sastry's Essentials of Medical Microbiology, 2nd Edition, Page 697

questions.question: Which of the following findings in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) would most strongly suggest a diagnosis of Neisseria meningitidis infection?

options.A: Low Neutrophil count, normal protein, normal glucose
options.B: High Neutrophil count, high protein, low glucose
options.C: High Neutrophil count, low protein, normal glucose
options.D: Low Neutrophil count, high protein, high glucose

questions.explanation: characteristic of bacterial meningitis, including meningitis caused by Neisseria meningitidis. A high Neutrophil count indicates an inflammatory response, high protein levels indicate increased permeability of the blood-brain barrier, and low glucose levels indicate bacterial consumption of glucose in the CSF. Lab Investigations of N. Meningitidis: Investigation Findings Cerebrospinal Fluid (CSF) Analysis Appearance Cloudy or purulent White Blood Cell Count (WBC) Elevated (pleocytosis), typically >1,000 cells/µL, with predominance of neutrophils Protein Elevated Glucose Decreased Gram Stain Presence of gram-negative diplococci Culture Growth of Neisseria meningitidis on chocolate agar or Thayer-Martin agar Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) Detection of Neisseria meningitidis DNA Latex Agglutination Test Positive for Neisseria meningitidis antigens Blood Tests Culture Growth of Neisseria meningitidis White Blood Cell Count Elevated leukocytosis with left shift CSF findings in Meningitis: Parameter Bacterial Meningitis Viral (Aseptic) Meningitis Fungal Meningitis Tuberculous Meningitis Appearance Cloudy or purulent Clear or slightly cloudy Clear or slightly cloudy Clear or slightly cloudy, Cob web coagulum White Blood Cell Count Elevated (usually >1,000 cells/µL) Predominantly neutrophils ( ≥ 80%) Elevated (usually 50-1,000 cells/µL) Predominantly lymphocytes Elevated (usually 20-500 cells/µL) Predominantly lymphocytes Elevated (usually 50-500 cells/µL) Predominantly lymphocytes Protein Elevated (100-500 mg/dL) Mildly elevated or normal (50-100 mg/dL) Elevated (100-500 mg/dL) Elevated (100-500 mg/dL) Glucose Decreased (<40 mg/dL or <2.2 mmol/L) Normal or slightly decreased Decreased Decreased CSF/Blood Glucose Ratio <0.4 >0.6 <0.4 <0.4 Opening Pressure Elevated Normal or slightly elevated Elevated Elevated Gram Stain Positive for bacteria (gram-negative diplococci, etc.) Negative Negative Negative

questions.question: Which of the following tests would best help to differentiate Neisseria meningitidis from Neisseria gonorrhoeae in this clinical context?
questions.explanation: N. meningitidis from N. gonorrhoeae based on their ability to oxidize different sugars. N. meningitidis oxidizes both glucose and maltose, while N. gonorrhoeae oxidizes only glucose. Differences between N. Gonorrhoeae and N. Meningitidis: Characteristic Neisseria gonorrhoeae Neisseria meningitidis Morphology Gram-negative diplococci Kidney shaped Gram-negative diplococci with capsule Oxidase Test Positive Positive Catalase Test Positive Positive Habitat Human genitourinary tract Human nasopharynx Transmission Sexual contact Respiratory droplets, close contact Diseases Caused Gonorrhea, pelvic inflammatory disease, conjunctivitis in newborns Meningitis, septicemia (meningococcemia) Virulence Factors Pili, outer membrane proteins, lipooligosaccharides (LOS) Polysaccharide capsule, pili, outer membrane proteins, LOS Culture Media Thayer-Martin agar, Chocolate agar Thayer-Martin agar, Chocolate agar Carbohydrate Utilization Glucose positive, maltose negative Glucose positive, maltose positive Superoxol Test Strong positive with 30% hydrogen peroxide Weak or negative reaction Antibiotic Resistance Increasing resistance, especially to penicillin and fluoroquinolones Generally susceptible to penicillin, but resistance can occur Vaccination No vaccine available Vaccines available for various serogroups (A, C, W, Y, B) Epidemiology Common STD worldwide Causes outbreaks, especially in crowded settings Oxidase test (Option A) : Both Neisseria meningitidis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae are oxidase positive. Gram stain morphology (Option B): Both organisms appear as gram-negative diplococci on Gram stain. This test helps to identify the general appearance of the bacteria. Bile esculin test (Option C): It is typically used to differentiate enterococci and group D streptococci, which can hydrolyze esculin in the presence of bile. Reference: Mahon and Lehman, Textbook of Diagnostic Microbiology, 6th Edition, Page 369, 370, 371, 372, 373, 374, 375, 376, 377, 378 Murray's Medical Microbiology, 9th Edition, Page 99, 145 Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th Edition, Page 231, 232, 233, 234, 235, 236, 237

questions.question: A clinical microbiology laboratory is performing biochemical tests to identify a strain of gamma-hemolytic streptococci isolated from a blood culture. Which of the following tests would be most appropriate to differentiate Streptococcus bovis from other gamma-hemolytic streptococci?
questions.explanation: (e.g., Enterococcus faecalis , Enterococcus faecium ) from other streptococci. Streptococcus bovis is positive in this test due to its ability to hydrolyze esculin in the presence of bile. Gamma-hemolytic streptococci (also known as non-hemolytic streptococci) do not lyse red blood cells , so they do not produce a clear zone around colonies on blood agar. They can grow in the presence of 40% bile, 6.5% NaCl, pH 9.6, and 45 degrees Celsius and can be further classified into different groups based on their biochemical and serological characteristics Includes groups such as Streptococcus bovis , Streptococcus equinus , and others within the Enterococcus genus. These organisms are often part of the normal flora of the gastrointestinal tract but can also cause infections in humans, particularly in immunocompromised individuals. Clinical Relevance Infections : Can cause a range of infections including urinary tract infections, bacteremia, intra-abdominal infections, and wound infections. Endocarditis : Streptococcus bovis is particularly associated with infective endocarditis, often in patients with underlying gastrointestinal malignancies or colon disorders. Laboratory Diagnosis Gram Stain : Gram-positive oval cocci are often arranged in chains or pairs. Culture : Growth on blood agar without hemolysis. Growth on Mac Conkey medium- tiny magenta colony Biochemical Tests : Differentiation within the group using tests like bile esculin agar (positive for Enterococcus ), PYR test (positive for Enterococcus ), and other biochemical markers. Treatment Antibiotics : Generally susceptible to penicillin and ampicillin , although some strains, especially within the Enterococcus genus, may exhibit resistance to multiple antibiotics. Treatment of Endocarditis: Combination therapy with aminoglycosides (e.g., gentamicin) is often used for synergy, particularly in cases of enterococcal endocarditis. Epidemiology Common in the gastrointestinal tract, especially in elderly or immunocompromised patients Streptococcus bovis is associated with colorectal cancer and inflammatory bowel disease, warranting screening for these conditions in patients with the bacterium Optochin susceptibility test (Option A) is used to differentiate Streptococcus pneumoniae (susceptible to optochin) from other alpha-hemolytic streptococci. PYR test (Option B) is used to identify group A streptococci ( Streptococcus pyogenes ), which are beta-hemolytic. It is also used to further classify gamma haemolytic Streptococcus. CAMP test (Option D) is used to identify group B streptococci ( Streptococcus agalactiae ) by demonstrating enhanced hemolysis when plated adjacent to a Staphylococcus aureus streak.

questions.question: A 65-year-old woman with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) presents to her primary care physician for an annual check-up. She asks about vaccines recommended for adults to prevent pneumonia. Which of the following vaccines would be most appropriate to recommend to this patient?
questions.explanation: adults over 65 years old and younger adults with certain medical conditions, such as COPD, chronic heart disease, or diabetes. It covers a broader range of pneumococcal serotypes compared to PCV and helps prevent pneumococcal pneumonia and invasive diseases in adults. Treatment for Strep Pneumoniae Vaccines for Strep Pneumoniae Penicillin and Penicillin Derivatives : Effective for susceptible strains of Streptococcus pneumoniae. High-dose penicillin G or amoxicillin is the treatment of choice for non-severe infections. Cephalosporins : Such as ceftriaxone or cefotaxime are used for more severe infections or in patients with penicillin allergy. Macrolides : Such as erythromycin or azithromycin, may be used in cases of resistance or intolerance to beta-lactams. Supportive care including antipyretics, oxygen therapy, and fluids as needed. Pneumococcal Conjugate Vaccine (PCV) : Contains polysaccharide antigens from the most common serotypes of Streptococcus pneumoniae conjugated to a carrier protein. Recommended for infants and young children to prevent invasive pneumococcal disease (IPD), pneumonia, and otitis media. (Option A ruled out) It's a seven-valent conjugate vaccine. Pneumococcal Polysaccharide Vaccine (PPSV) : Covers a broader range of pneumococcal serotypes compared to PCV. Recommended for adults over 65 years old, and younger adults with certain medical conditions (e.g., immunocompromised, chronic heart or lung disease). Varicella vaccine (Option B) is used to prevent chickenpox caused by the Varicella zoster virus. It is recommended for the elderly but is not relevant for preventing pneumococcal infections in adults. Hib vaccine (Option C) is used to prevent infections caused by Haemophilus influenzae type b, such as meningitis, pneumonia, and epiglottitis, primarily in children under 5 years old. Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th Edition, Page 228, 229 Murray's Medical Microbiology, 9th Edition, Page 99, 145, 163, 164 Mahon and Lehman, Textbook of Diagnostic Microbiology, 6th Edition, Page 331, 332

questions.question: A 60-year-old man presents to the emergency department with high fever, chills, productive cough with rust-colored sputum, and pleuritic chest pain. His medical history is significant for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). A chest X-ray reveals a lobar consolidation. Sputum Gram stain shows gram-positive, lancet-shaped diplococci. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in confirming the diagnosis?

options.C: Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) test on the sputum
options.D: Bile solubility test on the sputum sample

questions.explanation: pneumococcal diseases, including pneumonia, as they can identify the presence of bacteria in the bloodstream and confirm the diagnosis. The success of this test is directly related to the methods used to collect the blood sample. The most important factor that determines the success of a blood culture is the volume of blood p rocessed. Approximately 20 ml of blood should be collected from an adult for each blood culture, and proportionally smaller volumes should be collected from children and neonates. Blood cultures are more specific and help confirm systemic involvement , which is important in moderate to severe pneumonia. Diseases caused by Strep pneumonia: Pneumonia Community-acquired pneumonia, is often characterized by rapid onset, high fever, chills, pleuritic chest pain, and productive cough with rust-colored sputum. Meningitis A common cause of bacterial meningitis in adults and children, presenting with symptoms like headache, fever, neck stiffness, photophobia, and altered mental status. Otitis Media A frequent cause of middle ear infections in children, characterized by ear pain, fever, irritability, and sometimes hearing loss. Sinusitis Causes acute sinus infections, presenting with facial pain, nasal congestion, purulent nasal discharge, and fever. Endocarditis Can cause endocarditis, particularly in individuals with pre-existing heart conditions. Lab investigations- Gram Stain : Gram-positive, lancet-shaped diplococci. Useful in the initial identification of clinical specimens like sputum, blood, or cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) Culture Grows well on blood agar, producing alpha-hemolytic (greenish) colonies. Optochin sensitivity test: S. pneumoniae is sensitive to optochin, differentiating it from other alpha-hemolytic streptococci. Bile solubility test: S. pneumoniae is bile soluble, confirming its identity Blood Culture Critical for diagnosing invasive pneumococcal disease and guiding antibiotic therapy. Antigen Detection : Latex agglutination or immunochromatographic tests for pneumococcal antigens in urine or CSF. Rapid diagnostic tool, especially useful in meningitis cases. Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) Detection of pneumococcal DNA in clinical specimens. Highly sensitive and specific, useful for diagnosing invasive pneumococcal disease Quellung Reaction : Capsular swelling test where specific antisera cause the capsule of S. pneumoniae to swell, confirming its presence and serotype Throat swab culture (Option A) is not appropriate for diagnosing pneumonia. They are primarily used for diagnosing streptococcal pharyngitis, which is typically caused by Streptococcus pyogenes. Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) test on the sputum (Option C): While PCR is highly sensitive and specific for detecting pneumococcal DNA, it is not typically the first step in standard diagnostic protocols Bile solubility test on the sputum sample (Option D) is

questions.question: A 62-year-old female with a history of rheumatic heart disease and a prosthetic mitral valve undergoes a tooth extraction. Two weeks later, she presents with fever, night sweats, and malaise. Blood cultures reveal alpha-hemolytic Streptococcus viridans. Transesophageal echocardiography shows vegetations on the mitral valve. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

options.A: Start oral amoxicillin and schedule follow-up in one week.
options.B: Admit to the hospital and start intravenous ceftriaxone and gentamicin.
options.C: Discharge with a prescription for oral clindamycin and instruct her to return if symptoms worsen.

questions.explanation: Intravenous ceftriaxone and gentamicin are often used together in treating infective endocarditis caused by Streptococcus viridans, especially in patients with prosthetic valves, as combination therapy can be synergistic and more effective in eradicating the infection. Most commonly affecting prosthetic valve <12 months after replacement- Staph epidermidis More than 12 months after replacement- Strep viridans Alpha Hemolytic Streptococcus: Part of the normal flora of the human mouth, throat, and gastrointestinal tract. Exhibits alpha-hemolysis on blood agar, leading to a partial or greenish discoloration around colonies. Includes multiple species such as S. mitis, S. mutans, S. sanguinis (leads to SABE), and S. salivarius. Epidemiology : Dental procedures can introduce Streptococcus viridans into the bloodstream, potentially leading to infective endocarditis. Patients with pre-existing heart conditions, such as valvular heart disease or prosthetic valves, are at higher risk. Infection Mechanism : Capable of producing biofilms, aiding in adherence to heart valves, and resistance to phagocytosis and antibiotics. Production of extracellular polysaccharides enhances its ability to colonize and persist in host tissues. Clinical Presentation : Symptoms can include fever, chills, heart murmur, fatigue, and signs of embolic events such as petechiae or splinter hemorrhages. Complications may involve heart failure, systemic embolization, and severe valve dysfunction. Diagnosis : Blood cultures are essential for identifying the causative organism. Echocardiography (especially transesophageal echocardiography) is used to visualize vegetations on the heart valves Treatment : Prolonged antibiotic therapy, often involves penicillin or ceftriaxone combined with an aminoglycoside. In some cases, surgical intervention may be necessary to repair or replace damaged valves. Start oral amoxicillin and schedule follow-up in one week (Option A): Oral antibiotics are not appropriate for treating endocarditis due to the need for high, sustained bactericidal concentrations in the bloodstream. Discharge with a prescription for oral clindamycin and instruct her to return if symptoms worsen (Option C): Oral antibiotics are not appropriate for treating endocarditis due to the need for high, sustained bactericidal concentrations in the bloodstream. Schedule urgent valve replacement surgery (Option D): While valve replacement surgery ( Option D ) may eventually be necessary, the immediate next step is to control the infection with appropriate intravenous antibiotics. Surgery is considered if there is severe valve dysfunction, heart failure, or persistent infection despite antibiotics. Reference: Mahon and Lehman, Textbook of Diagnostic Microbiology, 6th Edition, Page 332, 333, 334, Bailey & Scott's Diagnostic Microbiology, 14th Edition, Page 275, 284, Murray's Medical Microbiology, 9th Edition, Page

questions.question: A 36-week pregnant woman presents for routine prenatal care. Her GBS culture from 35 weeks gestation is positive. Which of the following is the most appropriate management strategy for this patient during labor?

options.A: Administer intravenous ampicillin every 4 hours until delivery
options.B: Prescribe oral penicillin for 7 days prior to expected delivery date
options.C: Administer a single dose of intramuscular ceftriaxone at the onset of labor
options.D: No antibiotic prophylaxis needed; treat the newborn empirically after birth

questions.explanation: ampicillin (or penicillin) administered every 4 hours during labor until delivery is the recommended intrapartum antibiotic prophylaxis (IAP) for GBS-positive mothers. This approach significantly reduces the risk of early-onset GBS disease in newborns. GBS prevention: 1. Screening : Universal screening of pregnant women at 35-37 weeks gestation is recommended in many countries. 2. Indications for IAP: Positive GBS screening culture during current pregnancy GBS bacteriuria during current pregnancy Previous infant with invasive GBS disease Unknown GBS status with risk factors (preterm labor, prolonged rupture of membranes, intrapartum fever) 3. Antibiotics: First-line: Penicillin G or Ampicillin For penicillin-allergic patients: Cefazolin (if low risk for anaphylaxis) or Clindamycin/Vancomycin (if high risk for anaphylaxis and isolate susceptible) In case the newborn gets infected, antibiotics like penicillin and other supportive management are used for treatment. Prescribe oral penicillin for 7 days prior to expected delivery date (Option B): Oral antibiotics are not effective for GBS prophylaxis. The colonization often recurs after oral treatment, and the timing of labor onset is unpredictable. Administer a single dose of intramuscular ceftriaxone at the onset of labor (Option C): While ceftriaxone is active against GBS, a single intramuscular dose is not the recommended regimen. Continuous intravenous therapy during labor is necessary to maintain adequate antibiotic levels. No antibiotic prophylaxis needed; treat the newborn empirically after birth (Option D): No antibiotic prophylaxis needed; treat the newborn empirically after birth: This approach is not recommended as it fails to prevent vertical transmission of GBS during labor and delivery. Reference: Murray's Medical Microbiology, 9th Edition, Page 205, 206 Bailey & Scott's Diagnostic Microbiology, 14th Edition, Page 267, 268 Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th Edition, Page 212, 213 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK482443/

questions.question: A 28-year-old pregnant woman at 36 weeks gestation undergoes routine screening for Group B Streptococcus (GBS). The vaginal-rectal swab culture shows beta-hemolytic colonies on blood agar. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step to confirm GBS?

options.B: Conduct a latex agglutination test for group B antigen

questions.explanation: is a simple and specific test for presumptive identification of Streptococcus agalactiae (GBS). It detects the CAMP factor, a protein produced by GBS that enhances the hemolytic activity of Staphylococcus aureus beta-lysin. A positive CAMP reaction is indicated by an arrowhead-shaped zone of enhanced hemolysis where the GBS streak approaches the S. aureus streak. GBS Diagnosis: 1. Culture on blood agar (beta-hemolytic colonies) 2. CAMP test (presumptive identification) 3. Latex agglutination or nucleic acid amplification tests for confirmation 4. Hippurate hydrolysis test (positive for GBS) 5. Resistance to bacitracin and optochin GBS Treatment: 1. For neonatal sepsis: Ampicillin plus gentamicin empirically; adjust based on susceptibility 2 . For maternal colonization: Intrapartum antibiotic prophylaxis with penicillin G or ampicillin 3. For penicillin-allergic patients: Cefazolin (if low risk for anaphylaxis) or clindamycin/vancomycin (if high risk for anaphylaxis and isolate susceptible) Conduct a latex agglutination test for group B antigen (Option B): Latex agglutination test for GBS is typically used for rapid detection from clinical specimens or for confirming isolates. The CAMP test is more cost-effective for initial presumptive identification. Observe for orange pigment production (Option C): While some strains of GBS can produce an orange pigment, this characteristic is not consistent across all strains and is not a reliable method for identification. Perform a bacitracin sensitivity test (Option D): The Bacitracin sensitivity test is primarily used for differentiating Group A Streptococcus (S. pyogenes), which is typically bacitracin-sensitive. It is not useful for identifying GBS.

questions.question: A full-term newborn develops respiratory distress, lethargy, and poor feeding within 24 hours of birth. The mother had no prenatal care. Blood culture grows gram-positive cocci in chains. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Streptococcal (GBS)/ Streptococcus agalactiae disease typically presents within the first 24-48 hours of life. The clinical features of respiratory distress, lethargy, and poor feeding are classic signs of neonatal sepsis. The gram-positive cocci in chains from the blood culture are consistent with GBS. The unknown GBS status of the mother increases the risk for this condition. Prevention strategies focus on screening pregnant women at 35-37 weeks gestation and providing intrapartum antibiotic prophylaxis to GBS-positive mothers. Conditions caused by GBS in neonates: Condition Onset Clinical Features Diagnosis Treatment Complications Neonatal Sepsis Early-Onset (0-6 days)/ Late-Onset (7-89 days) Fever, irritability, lethargy, poor feeding, respiratory distress Blood cultures, CSF analysis, PCR Ampicillin + gentamicin or cefotaxime Meningitis, pneumonia, death Neonatal Meningitis Late-Onset (7-89 days) Fever, irritability, poor feeding, bulging fontanelle CSF analysis, blood cultures, PCR Ampicillin + gentamicin or cefotaxime Neurological sequelae, hydrocephalus, death Neonatal Pneumonia Early-Onset (0-6 days) Respiratory distress, tachypnea, grunting, cyanosis Chest X-ray, blood cultures, PCR Ampicillin + gentamicin or cefotaxime Respiratory failure, sepsis, death In pregnant women: Urinary tract infections Chorioamnionitis Postpartum endometritis In adults: Skin and soft tissue infections Bacteremia Pneumonia Osteomyelitis Endocarditis Late-onset Group B Streptococcal disease (Option B): typically occurs between 1 week and 3 months of age. Listeria monocytogenes sepsis (Option C): While Listeria can cause neonatal sepsis, it is less common than GBS. Listeria typically appears as gram-positive rods. Escherichia coli sepsis (Option D): E. coli is a common cause of neonatal sepsis, but it is a gram-negative rod. Reference: Jawetz, Melnick, & Adelberg's Medical Microbiology, 28th Edition, Page 212-217. Bailey & Scott's Diagnostic Microbiology, 14th Edition, Page 351-357. Sherris Medical Microbiology, 7th Edition. Page 221-226.

questions.question: A 48-year-old woman has a purulent discharge from a surgical wound after an abdominal surgery performed two weeks ago. An analysis of the discharge, reveals Gram-positive cocci. Further testing shows that the organism is catalase-positive and coagulase-negative. What is the most likely organism?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Staphylococcus epidermidis Explanation: Staphylococcus epidermidis is present on normal human skin and is the most common cause of CoNS infections in humans. When the host's defenses are breached (in this scenario it is the surgery), stitch abscess frequently results from it. questions.question: A 6-year-old boy presents with fever, sore throat, and rash that started on the neck and chest and then spread to the trunk and extremities. Examination findings are given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 7-year-old boy presents with fever, sore throat, and enlarged cervical lymph nodes. Throat culture grows beta-hemolytic colonies on blood agar, and the isolate is identified as Streptococcus pyogenes. Which of the following virulence factors of S. pyogenes is primarily responsible for its ability to resist phagocytosis and contribute to invasive infections?
questions.explanation: (Group A Streptococcus) that plays a crucial role in resisting phagocytosis. It's an anti-phagocytic surface protein that interferes with complement activation and opsonization, allowing the bacteria to evade the host's immune defenses. The M protein also plays a role in adherence to epithelial cells and is implicated in the post-streptococcal sequelae due to molecular mimicry with human tissues Virulence Factor Description Mechanism of Action Associated Diseases M Protein (Option B) Surface protein Resists phagocytosis by inhibiting opsonization, interacts with host cell receptors Pharyngitis, rheumatic fever Streptolysin O and S (Option A) Hemolysins Lyse red and white blood cells, and platelets; cause tissue damage Pharyngitis, skin infections Streptococcal Pyrogenic Exotoxins (SPEs) Exotoxins Act as superantigens, causing a massive immune response; associated with scarlet fever and streptococcal toxic shock syndrome Scarlet fever, toxic shock-like syndrome (TSLS) Hyaluronidase (Option D) Enzyme Degrades hyaluronic acid in the host's connective tissue, facilitating bacterial spread Cellulitis, necrotizing fasciitis Streptokinase (Option C) Enzyme Converts plasminogen to plasmin, dissolving blood clots and facilitating spread Deep tissue infections, pharyngitis DNases (A, B, C, D) Enzymes Depolymerize free DNA in pus, reducing viscosity and aiding the spread Abscess formation, skin infections C5a Peptidase Enzyme Degrades the C5a component of the complement system, inhibiting chemotaxis of phagocytes Immune evasion, systemic infections Capsule Polysaccharide capsule Composed of hyaluronic acid; inhibits phagocytosis Severe invasive diseases, immune evasion Reference: Apurba Sastry's Essentials of Medical Microbiology, 2nd Edition, Pages 207-208. Jawetz, Melnick & Adelberg's Medical Microbiology, 28th Edition, Page 231.

questions.question: A 60-year-old diabetic patient presents with a persistent fever and septicemia. Blood cultures show alpha-hemolytic growth on blood agar. Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for this patient's condition?
questions.explanation: alpha-hemolytic streptococcus commonly causing pneumonia, septicemia, and meningitis, especially in diabetic patients and those with other underlying health issues. Classification of Streptococcus Based on Hemolysis : Hemolytic Activity Example Species Characteristics Alpha-hemolytic S. pneumoniae, (Option C) S. viridans Partial hemolysis, greenish color Beta-hemolytic S. pyogenes, (Option A) S. agalactiae (Option B) Complete hemolysis, clear zone Gamma-hemolytic S. bovis, (Option D) Enterococcus No hemolysis Lancefield Classification of Beta-hemolytic Streptococci : Based on specific carbohydrate antigens on cell walls Groups: A-H, K-V (excluding I and J) Lancefield Group Key Species Associated Infections Group A Streptococcus pyogenes Strep throat, impetigo, erysipelas, cellulitis, necrotizing fasciitis, rheumatic fever, glomerulonephritis Group B Streptococcus agalactiae Neonatal meningitis, sepsis, infections in immunocompromised adults Group C Streptococcus equisimilis Pharyngitis, endocarditis Group F Various Streptococcus species Rare, "minute streptococci", infections in various body sites Group G Various Streptococcus species Tonsillitis, endocarditis, urinary tract infections

questions.question: A 26-year-old sexually active female comes with complaints of burning micturition and haematuria. On investigation, the causative agent is a gram-positive coccus which is coagulase-negative. What is the most likely organism?
questions.explanation: coccus and is coagulase-negative. In a sexually active, the most common cause of a UTI, with the above features, is Staphylococcus saprophyticus. Coagulase-negative staphylococci (CoNS) are part of the human body's normal flora. Significant species include: Staphylococcus epidermidis Staphylococcus saprophyticus Staphylococcus haemolyticus Staphylococcus lugdunensis Staphylococcus saprophyticus : Commonly found on human skin and periurethral area Causes urinary tract infections- second most common cause, especially in sexually active young women Generally susceptible to most antibiotics Resistant to nalidixic acid Identifiable by its novobiocin resistance Infections Caused by CoNS : Staphylococcus epidermidis : The most prevalent cause of CoNS infections Commonly found on human skin Conditions caused by Staphylococcus epidermidis : Bacteremia Implanted foreign bodies Cystitis Compromised defenses Bloodstream infections Central lines Endocarditis Drug addicts Condition caused by Staphylococcus saprophyticus : Urinary tract infections Sexually active young women Antibiotic resistance Nalidixic acid, novobiocin Staphylococcus epidermidis (Option A): is also coagulase-negative, but it is more commonly associated with infections related to indwelling medical devices or prosthetic materials. Staphylococcus aureus (Option B): is a coagulase-positive organism Staphylococcus haemolyticus (Option D): causes severe infections in several body systems including meningitis, endocarditis, prosthetic joint infections, and bacteremia, and is prevalent in the hospital environment Reference: Textbook of Microbiology, Ananthanarayan & Paniker, 6th Edition, Page, 208.

questions.question: A 45-year-old male patient presented with a skin infection and he was started on benzylpenicillin. A culture was done when the patient failed to respond to the given treatment and methicillin resistance was detected. Which of the following drugs can be given to this patient?
questions.explanation: Staphylococcus aureus and the suitable drug for the same is Vancomycin. Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) Definition : MRSA is a type of Staphylococcus aureus resistant to methicillin and other β -lactam antibiotics. Common Habitats : Found on human skin and mucous membranes; typically harmless unless entering through damaged skin. Resistance Mechanism Cause: Resistance arises from the Staphylococcal chromosomal cassette for methicillin resistance (SCCmec). Key Proteins: MecA: An alternative penicillin-binding protein encoded by SCCmec, not recognized by β -lactam antibiotics. MecI and MecR1: Regulate MecA synthesis upon exposure to methicillin or other β -lactams. Diagnostic Methods: Diagnostic Method Description Culture-based techniques Use of chromogenic agar media where MRSA colonies appear pink, and other bacteria appear blue. Blood Sample Testing 10–20 ml of venous blood is drawn and injected into two culture bottles, incubated aerobically and anaerobically at 35°C. Automated systems detect growth via turbidity, fluorescence, O2 consumption, or CO2 production. Most bacteria are recovered within 2 days. Gram staining and specialized media are used for further identification. CSF Sample Testing For suspected meningitis, a lumbar puncture is performed to obtain 3–5 ml of CSF. Turbidity and high leukocyte counts indicate infection. CSF is Gram-stained and inoculated onto selective culture media. Antibiotic Susceptibility Testing- Confirmation of infection is followed by testing to determine the best treatment strategy. Treatment Challenge Treatment Options: Vancomycin: Effective but challenged by vancomycin-resistant strains (VRSA) (Option B). Linezolid: Primary treatment for VRSA especially Lung infections for other infections Daptomycin is used. Concerns: Emergence of vancomycin-intermediate Staphylococcus aureus (VISA) with reduced vancomycin susceptibility and thickened cell walls Tetracyclines Sulpha-drugs. Feature VISA VRSA Full Name Vancomycin-Intermediate Staphylococcus aureus Vancomycin-Resistant Staphylococcus aureus Resistance Level Intermediate resistance to vancomycin High resistance to vancomycin MIC (Minimum Inhibitory Concentration) 4-8 µg/mL ≥ 16 µg/mL Mechanism of Resistance Thickened cell wall leading to reduced penetration of vancomycin Acquisition of vanA gene from Enterococcus, altering the target site of vancomycin Treatment Options Higher doses of vancomycin, linezolid, daptomycin, or alternative agents Linezolid, daptomycin, quinupristin-dalfopristin, or alternative agents Prevalence More common than VRSA, but still relatively rare Very rare compared to VISA Clinical Significance This can lead to treatment failure with standard vancomycin dosing Represents a significant therapeutic challenge due to high-level resistance Other Options (Ceftazidime, Ceftriaxone, and Amoxicillin): are β -lactam antibiotics and therefore are ineffective against MRSA.

questions.question: Consider the following statements. Statement A: Differentiates Staphylococcus aureus from other staphylococci species. Statement B: Differentiates tubercle bacilli from atypical mycobacteria and indicates isoniazid sensitivity.

options.A: Statement A is true for a catalase test.
options.B: Statement B is true for a coagulase test.
options.C: Statement A is true for a coagulase test.
options.D: Both statements are true for a catalase test.v

questions.explanation: Staphylococcus aureus from other staphylococci species. Coagulase Test: Catalase Test: Purpose: Differentiates Staphylococcus aureus from other staphylococci species. Methods: Tube Test: Detects free coagulase (extracellular enzyme produced by S. aureus). Bacterial culture mixed with plasma in a tube. Positive if plasma clots. Slide Test: Detects bound coagulase (clumping factor, bound to bacterial cell wall). Bacteria mixed with plasma on a slide. Positive if bacteria clump together. Purpose: Tests for production of catalase enzyme. All Staphylococci produce catalase. Catalase neutralises hydrogen peroxide’s antibacterial properties. It differentiates staphylococci form streptococci Reference: Textbook of Microbiology, Ananthanarayan & Paniker, 6th Edition, Page, 207 https://asm.org/getattachment/72a871fc-ba92-4128-a194-6f1bab5c3ab7/Catalase-Test-Protocol.pdf

questions.question: A 45-year-old diabetic patient presents with a chronic foot ulcer showing signs of infection. Which laboratory test is most appropriate for identifying the causative organism, suspected to be Staphylococcus aureus?
questions.explanation: primary method for isolating and identifying bacterial pathogens from clinical samples. It is the gold standard method for isolating and identifying bacterial pathogens from clinical specimens. Staphylococcus aureus typically forms creamy white colonies on blood agar plates, which helps in its identification Step: Description: Specimen Collection Pus samples from suppurative lesions, sputum for respiratory infections, nasal swabs for carriers Direct Microscopy Gram staining reveals Gram-positive cocci in clusters, indicating staphylococci presence (Option A) Grape bunch- appearance Culture Culturing on blood agar to isolate and identify S. aureus colonies (Option C) Blood agar: beta hemolysis Nutrient agar: golden colonies Selective Media Salt-milk agar, Ludlam's medium, or Roberts' cooked meat medium to isolate S. aureus from mixed samples Mannitol salt agar - yellow color from S. aureus fermenting mannitol Biochemical Reactions Coagulase test: Detects S. aureus by its ability to clot plasma (positive result indicates S. aureus) Catalase test: Positive Antimicrobial Susceptibility Testing Determines antibiotic sensitivity to guide treatment decisions (Option D) Molecular Methods PCR to detect specific genes like mecA, associated with antibiotic resistance (Option B) Typing Method Description Examples Phenotypic Typing Relies on observable characteristics like antibiotic susceptibility or bacteriophage response. Method: Classifies strains based on susceptibility to specific bacteriophages. Limitations: Not all cultures are typeable; susceptibility patterns can change. Bacteriophage typing Genotypic Typing Analyzes genetic characteristics of bacteria for strain differentiation. Benefits: Offers higher discriminatory power, valuable in outbreak investigations. DNA fingerprinting (e.g., RFLP, ribotyping) PCR-based methods, PFGE, MLST

questions.question: A 21-year-old woman presents with high fever, diffuse macular rash, hypotension, purulent vaginal discharge, and desquamation of the skin on her palms and soles. She has used tampons during her recent menstrual cycle and forgot to remove them on time. Laboratory tests reveal a Gram-positive, catalase-positive, coagulase-positive coccus. Which toxin is primarily responsible for the condition observed in this patient?
questions.explanation: Toxic shock syndrome due to tampon use, which is often associated with Staphylococcus aureus. Bacteria produce Toxic shock syndrome toxin, a superantigen that can trigger a massive immune response causing high fever, rash, hypotension, and desquamation. Disease caused by staphylococcus Key features Primary infection Furuncle Superficial skin infection develops in hair follicles, sebaceous gland, or sweat gland. Carbuncle Development of one or more abscesses in adjacent subcutaneous tissues due to the spread of infection from a furuncle. Impetigo The exfoliative toxin produced causes bullous impetigo, characterized by blisters. Non-bullous impetigo is caused by streptococcus. Acute osteomyelitis Bacterial growth usually concentrates in a terminal blood artery of the metaphysis of a long bone, resulting in bone necrosis and persistent suppuration. Necrotizing pneumonia Caused by strains producing the PVL leukocidin. Localized, destructive abscesses Endocarditis In drug addicts Due to bacteremia Toxins mediated Scalded skin syndrome Erythema and intraepidermal desquamation in neonates caused by exfoliative toxin (Option B) Toxic shock syndrome TSST-1 (Toxic Shock Syndrome Toxin) Early findings: Fever, vomiting, diarrhea, muscle pain Later: Shock, renal, and hepatic injury, MODS Tampon-associated Staphylococcal food poisoning Vomiting is prominent without fever. Ingestion of enterotoxin-contaminated food causing acute vomiting and diarrhea within 1 to 5 hours of ingestion (Option D) Beta-hemolysin is not responsible for Toxic shock syndrome (Option C) Reference: Jawetz Melnick & Adelbergs Medical Microbiology, 28th Edition, Pg 209 Sherris and Ryan’s Medical Microbiology, 8th Edition Page 915-918 Bailey & Scott's Diagnostic Microbiology, 15th Edition Page 254

questions.question: Bronchopneumonia due to Staphylococcus aureus infection is suspected in a 40-year-old patient. Which diagnostic test utilizes protein A to detect the presence of this bacteria?
questions.explanation: Staphylococcus aureus to be coated with antibodies. The coated bacteria are then used to detect the presence of Staphylococcus aureus antigens in the test sample through visible clumping. Coagulase test (Option A): Coagulase produced by Staphylococcus aureus causes the clotting of blood plasma by converting fibrinogen to fibrin. There are two types of coagulase tests: the slide coagulase test and the tube coagulase test. Oxidase test (Option C): is used to determine the presence of cytochrome oxidase in bacteria Catalase test (Option D): is used to identify the presence of the enzyme catalase in bacteria, which breaks down hydrogen peroxide (H I O I ) into water and oxygen.

questions.question: A 3-year-old child presents with fever, and widespread peeling of the skin, especially around the face and trunk. The causative organism is identified as a Gram-positive, catalase-positive, and coagulase-positive coccus. Which virulence factor of this organism is responsible for the clinical manifestation observed in this child?
questions.explanation: scalded skin syndrome (SSSS), which is caused due to the Epidermolytic/Exfoliative toxin of Staphylococcus aureus. Staphylococcal Scalded Skin Syndrome (SSSS) is a skin condition caused by Staphylococcus aureus bacteria that produce exfoliative toxins. These toxins cause the skin to blister and peel, resembling burns. Affects: Primarily infants and young children, but can also occur in immunocompromised adults. Symptoms: Fever, red, tender skin that blisters and peels, especially on the face and neck. Nikolsky's sign (skin sloughing with pressure) is often positive. Diagnosis: Clinical, supported by bacterial cultures or detection of exfoliative toxins. Treatment: Antibiotics (e.g., nafcillin, clindamycin) and supportive care (fluids, wound care). Prognosis: Good with prompt treatment, though severe cases can be life-threatening in infants or immunocompromised individuals . Virulence factors Key features Cell wall-associated polymers Peptidoglycan Activates complement-induced release of inflammatory cytokines Teichoic acid Adherence to the host cell surface, and shields them from complement-mediated opsonization Capsular polysaccharide Inhibits opsonization Cell surface Protein A Anti-complementary Anti-phagocytic Co-agglutination Clumping factor Responsible for the slide coagulase test Toxins Hemolysin (Option C) Alpha hemolysin- Lyse sheep and human red blood cells. Toxic to macrophages, lysosomes, muscle tissues, the renal cortex, and the circulatory system Beta-hemolysins or sphingomyelinase Lyse sheep red blood cells only Panton-Valentine (PVL) Leucocidin Synergohymenotropic toxin Attacks neutrophils, platelets Produced by Methicillin-Resistant Staph. aureus (MRSA) Enterotoxin (superantigen) Food poisoning Most cases are caused by type A. It acts directly on the autonomic nervous system causing symptoms. Vomiting is stimulated in the brain stem. Toxic shock syndrome toxin(TSST) (Option D) (superantigen) Fatal multisystem disease Tampon-related TSS Epidermolytic/Exfoliative toxin (Option A) Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS): the outer layer of the epidermis gets separated from the underlying tissues. Severe form of SSSS: Ritter's disease in the newborn and toxic epidermal necrolysis in older patients. Milder forms: pemphigus neonatorum and bullous impetigo Enzymes Coagulase (Option B) Clotting of human or rabbit plasma Lipid hydrolases Helps in skin and subcutaneous tissue infections Hyaluronidase Breaks down the connective tissues Staphylokinase, protease Nuclease Heat-stable DNase Reference: Textbook of Microbiology, Ananthanarayan & Paniker, 6th Edition, Page 203, 204, Sherris and Ryan’s Medical microbiology, 8th Edition, Page 906 Bailey & Scott's Diagnostic Microbiology, 15th Edition, Page 254

questions.question: A 28-year-old male presents with a purulent discharge from the wound. The laboratory identifies the causative bacteria to be gram-positive cocci, non-motile, non-spore-forming, catalase-positive, and coagulase-positive. Which notable characteristic of this organism is seen when cultured on nutrient agar helps in diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Staphylococcus aureus produces golden-yellow pigment. Key features of staphylococcus aureus: Morphology Gram-positive bacteria Spherical cocci, arranged in grape-like clusters Non-motile Non-spore forming Cultural characteristics Nutrient agar: Large colonies (2-4 mm in diameter), convex, smooth, shiny, opaque, and easily emulsifiable. They produce golden-yellow pigment (Option D), which does not diffuse into the medium. Blood agar: Marked hemolysis MacConkey agar: Pink colonies due to lactose fermentation (Option A) Biochemical characteristics: Coagulase test positive Catalase test positive Oxidase negative Incorrect options: Blue-green pigment (Option B): (Pyocyanin) is produced by Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Matt-finely granular colony (Option C): is characteristic of virulent strains of streptococcus pyogenes when grown in blood agar. Reference: Textbook of Microbiology, Ananthanarayan & Paniker, 6th Edition, Page 206, 217, 320, 321 Bailey & Scott's Diagnostic Microbiology, 15th Edition, Page 257
